 BULGARIA RAILWAY REHABILITATION PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY Borrower: Bulgarian State Railways (BDZ) Guarantor: Republic of Bulgaria Loan Amount: US$95.0 million equivalent Terms: Twenty years, including 5-year grace at the Banks's standard variable interest rate Project Objectives and Description: The objective of the project is to support the restructuring process which the BDZ and the Government have initiated. As the first Bank intervention in the sector, the project supports a set of policy measures that are or will be embodied in the new Railway Law, the RAP (Annex 1) and a Contract Plan with the Government. The project would only finance necessary investments which are in line with the restructuring concept and would help the railway through the restructuring process. These include: (a) Track Renewal and Maintenance on Priority Routes; (b) Management Information System (MIS); (c) Signalling and Telecommunications; (d) Traction and Rolling Stock Improvements; (e) Rehabilitation of Passenger Coaches; and (f) Technical Assistance and Training. Benefits and Risks: The immediate benefits will be resource savings resulting from the restructuring process and lower transport costs. The main risks are of policy slippage, due to changes in the political environment. Further deterioration of economic conditions in Bulgaria would pose a risk of lack of counterpart funds and reduced rail traffic. These risks are outside Bank control, so it is proposed to hold a mid-term review to assess progress in achieving the development objectives of the project and restructure it as necessary.  I. THE TRANSPORT SECTOR A. The Transport System 1. 1 Bulgaria is a medium size European country with an area of 112,000 sq. km and population of 9.0 million. The population density is low at 80 per sq. km. Per capita income in 1993 was estimated at about $1,400. At the end of World War II, the economy was based primarily on agriculture, but postwar development stressed industrialization. Bulgaria specialized in machinery, particularly electro-mechanical and electronics and chemicals. The heavy dependence on CMEA trade, which has been severely disrupted, greatly affected the Bulgarian economy in general and the transport sector in particular. 1.2 Bulgaria has about 37,000 km of roads of which 250 km of motorways. Road density, with regard to both population and land area, is the second lowest among Central and Eastern European (CEE) countries after Romania, with very little difference between the two countries. The rail network is 4,300 km of which 2,600 km are electrified and 900 km have double track. The Danube offers a navigable distance of some 500 km in Bulgaria. Varna and Burgas are the main ports on the Black Sea. B. Traffic 1.3 Bulgaria's transport sector has been somewhat less railway oriented than other centrally planned economies (Tables 1 and 2). In 1989, rail accounted for only 45% of the freight traffic (tkm) compared to 70% in neighboring Romania. Rail freight reached 80 million tons and 18 billion tkm in the late 80s, but has fallen dramatically since 1989. Since 1992, traffic stabilized around 30 million tons and 8 billion tkm or 57% less than in 1989. Passenger traffic held up better, being down about 36%. In recent years, the National Railways (BDZ) transported some 70 million passengers achieving more than 5.0 billion passenger-km (pkm). 1.4 Road traffic was, until recently, growing at about 4% annually, with heavy traffic growing at about 10% annually, although this growth has now been affected by the economic situation and the sanctions against the former Yugoslavia. The share of road transport, about 50%, is the highest in CEE countries, although well below Western European levels. 1.5 Port traffic has also fallen to nearly half of what it was in 1989. At Varma, traffic in 1993 and 1994 was about 6 million tons of which two-thirds were bulk and the rest general cargo. A similar situation prevails at the smaller port of Burgas. Container traffic is still small, each port handles only 10,000 TEU per year. River transport accounts for only 5% of land transport and pipelines for about 2%.
 - 2 - C. Institutions 1.6 The Ministry of Transport (MOT) oversees the sector as a whole. It has been reorganized to concentrate on policy making and regulatory functions rather than being an operator of transport means (Chart 1). Its staff has recently been reduced from 350 to 250. The road network is administered by the General Road Administration (GRA) and the rail transport by the Bulgarian State Railways (BDZ). The two principal ports, Varna and Burgas, are autonomous enterprises which are profitable, despite the fall in traffic. The MOT oversees a number of public enterprises operating road transport services, port and airport facilities as well as air transport services, but is in the process of privatizing many of them. D. Investments 1.7 In the 1980's, investments in the transport sector were around US$450 to 500 million per year. The share of railways investments fell from 35% of the total in 1980 to 25% in 1989, while the road and road transport share increased from less than 50% to over 60%. The share of water and air transport remained constant around 15% with some annual fluctuations reflecting purchase of ships or airplanes. In the last three years, investments in the sector have come to a virtual halt. For instance, in 1992, investments for the whole sector totalled US$24 million, only allowing for urgent repairs and periodic maintenance and no new investments (Table 3). E. Sectoral Issues 1.8 One of the main problems faced in defining a strategy for the sector is to forecast the future volumes and pattern of transport demand. The shift to a market economy is resulting in less emphasis on transport intensive industries such as steel, cement and petrochemicals and more on high value-added light industry and agro-industry. The latter will require lower transport volumes and are more likely to use road transport than rail or water transport. Railways are unlikely to recoup most of the lost traffic and will have to concentrate on developing new markets such as international freight and combined transport. On the passenger side, the need to increase tariffs to reduce the need for subsidies could moderate travel demand until income growth resumes. Growing competition from road transport, is also likely to dampen demand for rail passengers. 1.9 The sector was no exception to the general distortions resulting from administrative rather than market prices. In the past few years, there has been some progress and presently prices of road transport for freight and inter-city passenger services are freely set and fuel prices reflect world market prices. Railway tariffs however have remained controlled (para. 2.25). 1.10 In the eighties, investments in the sector were skewed toward new projects with little regard for economic and financial feasibility. On the other hand, funds for maintenance, rehabilitation and replacement of old equipment and modernization were scarce.
 - 3 - Due to this, and to the budget squeeze of the past few years, existing infrastructure and equipment are obsolete and service availability is low. The Bank, together with EBRD and EIB, is introducing the use of economic feasibility studies as a basis for improving decision making on investments. F. Sector Strategy and Bank Role 1.11 The following principles and policies are guiding the future action of Government, through its MOT, in the transport. sector: - preparing certain transport enterprises for privatization and for those, like the railways, which will remain state enterprises, organizing their restructuring; - decentralizing and demonopolizing transport activities - bringing the transport vehicles and infrastructure as well as their mode of operation in line with international standards and requirements of a market economy; - ensuring fair inter and intra-modal competition together with free modal choice by transport users; - guaranteeing safety and reliability of transport services and - protecting the environment in the development and operation of transport activities. This strategy is basically sound and forms a good basis for the work of the Ministry of Transport, which is to concentrate on regulatory functions and inspection to ensure safety and protection of the environment. 1.12 The proposed project will be the first Bank loan in the sector. The broad economic and political changes occurring in Eastern Europe have a considerable impact on their railway. Bulgaria is no exception. The need to restructure the railways is important not only for the transport sector but also from a macroeconomic point of view. The Bank together with EBRD, which financed a restructuring study completed in September 1993, can play a catalytic role in assisting the Government with the difficult, although necessary, restructuring process. 1.13 Against this background, the Bank's strategy in the transport sector is to promote efficiency in investments and in operations, through competitive environment and by attracting private investment wherever possible, promote sound pricing policies, and help ensure that environmental concerns are well handled. In the specific case of the railway, the Bank strategy is to support their downsizing to an economic level, complemented by measures to improve their efficiency thus controlling the need for public financing and to set
 the stage for future private sector participation. This strategy provides a strong linkage between the proposed operation and the objectives set in the CAS that was discussed by the Board on March 9, 1993, which emphasize macroeconomic stabilization, transformation of state enterprises and modernization of Bulgaria's physical infrastructure. II. THE RAILWAY SUBSECTOR A. Organization. Management and Staff 2.1 BDZ is an independent legal entity (established in 1989 under the authority of Resolution No. 50 of the Council of Ministers) and registered as a state-owned company. Besides the headquarters in Sofia, BDZ's operations are organized into four regions. The chief executive is the Director General, answerable to a Governing Council. This Council was reorganized in December 1993; it was reduced in size from 17 to 11 members and now has a majority of non-BDZ representatives. The Governing Council is expected to manage both the strategic and operational functions. 2.2 Until now, BDZ's organization was a conventional one for railways i.e. dominated by the technical functions of infrastructure, traction and rolling stock and operations. This structure is inappropriate for a market oriented railway. The restructuring study recommended commercial/marketing focused organization with two basic business groups - freight and passenger - and two service functions - infrastructure and finance. However, it also suggested that such a change had little chance to succeed if applied at once, and that an intermediate organizational structure, that would allow marketing and commercial skills to develop would be preferable. In March 1994, the Governing Council approved such an intermediate organization and it is gradually being put into place (Chart 2). Major features of the new organization are: (a) the creation of a strong Marketing and Product Development group under a Deputy Director General (DDG); (b) the consolidation under a single DDG of all track, signalling, telecommunications, catenary and power supply responsibilities under "Infrastructure"; and (c) the placing of all locomotives, coaches and freight cars under a DDG for "Traction and Rolling Stock". 2.3 Between 1989 and 1993, the total number of staff was reduced by 18,000 and by another 6,000 in 1994 for a total reduction of almost 30% (Table 4). At the end of 1994, BDZ employed about 58,000 persons, of which some 50,000 or 86% work in transport activities (including 27,000 operational, 15,000 infrastructure and 8,000 traction/rolling stock staff). Because staff cuts to date have not yet matched the loss of traffic, productivity (measured in traffic units per traffic employee) is 25% lower in 1994 than in 1989, however, it has been increasing regularly since the low point reached in 1991. BDZ is at the same time overstaffed for its reduced traffic level and short of staff with new skills such as marketing, financial management, computerization, etc. 2.4 BDZ plans to reduce staff by a further 10,000 by 1998 (see Annex 1, attachment 1) and this would restore productivity to the 1990 level, which was acceptable, even if traffic remains stable. Such staff reductions would result from: the closure of stations and lines; the reduction of wagon load traffic; the reduction in use of rolling stock
 fleet, installation of better equipment and improvement of working practices; and improved efficiency in the system at the whole. The staff reduction program should be complemented by an extensive training program coupled with a system of performance reward that the project will support. B. Railway Facilities Network 2.5 The Bulgarian railway system consists of about 4,300 route km including 245 km of narrow gauge (IBRD Map No. 26019). About 960 km or 22% are double track and 2640 km or 61 % electrified (25 Kv and 50 Hz). The network is in a relatively sound condition, but deteriorating, as maintenance expenditures have been drastically reduced. Much remedial work is required to prevent impairing safety and to prepare for future improvements. 2.6 The track is mainly 49 kg/m rail, with welded points (about 13% of total track ldlometers). It is laid on reinforced concrete sleepers, except on switches, crossing and curves where timber sleepers are used. Rails were imported from Poland, the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia. The ballast is supplied by BDZ's quarries with relatively low crushing strength and is not of acceptable quality. Under the project, all five quarries should be separated from BDZ with a view to privatization and ballast should be brought to UIC specifications. The concrete sleepers are produced in a BDZ factory at Svistov, with a capacity of about 200,000 p.a. The production technology is outdated (1966 level) and quality is not satisfactory. The existing factory will be modernized to produce higher quality sleepers with a view to become a commercial company and eventually to be privatized. The rail fastening is locally produced based on imported steel and on 1960 technology. BDZ is now planning to introduce modem technology for elastic fastenings. 2.7 About 10,000 switches and 250 double crossing throughout the system are severely worn out, imposing speed restrictions through the stations to ensure safety. Future relaying should introduce selectively a heavier rail section, minimum E-54 UIC rail profile, to allow increased axle loads. There are 982 bridges of which 337 are steel construction (all over 60 years old but strengthened for 23-25 ton axle loads) and 645 are concrete (6 bridges of suspect load capacity, subject to speed restriction up to 40 km/h). The total aggregate length of 183 tunnels is about 47 km. 2.8 Annually, some 500-600 km of track need periodic maintenance and 250-300 km need renewal (capital overhaul). In recent years, less than half of these amounts were performed due to lack of funds. The middle range maintenance is done by the maintenance department (RVP) of BDZ and the track renewal by the railway construction unit of MOT operated by the military. Pre-fabrication of track sections is undertaken by this unit which has the monopoly on all track lifting and relaying works. It was agreed that track renewal would gradually be done on the basis of contracts. During negotiations, assurances were given that equipment for track renewal and maintenance to be financed by the project will remain with BDZ and not be passed on to MOT's unit (para. 6.1 b).
 - 6 - 2.9 Most track maintenance equipment is beyond refurbishment (85% of RVP's equipment is overaged) and reliable heavy maintenance equipment and small tools are lacking. Therefore, track maintenance, and procurement of track maintenance machines, together with updated technology, is essential and high priority, necessary for safety reasons in train operation. In addition, major organizational changes and concentration of responsibilities together with staff training are needed. The major focus of the project is on track maintenance. The electrification system is also in need of urgent rehabilitation and replacement due to significant failures in power supplies and in overhead contact lines (OCL). Signalling and Telecommunications 2.10 The system is generally good, but some important stations need a new interlocking system on safety and commercial grounds. Half of the stations are equipped with signals of which about one-half are mechanical, electro-mechanical or key interlocking, locally produced or imported from the former Soviet Union or East Germany. Centralized Traffic Control (CTC) exists on the single line Sofia-Karlovo (equipment is of 1972 Russian origin - now totally obsolete, spares for which are no longer available) and Sofia-Plovdiv line (very modem installation, with computerized automatic routing - provided by ISKRA of the former Yugoslavia in 1989). Automatic Train Stopping equipment (ATS) were fitted on 103 locomotives and should be extended. There is a total of about 1,300 rail level crossings, of which about 570 or 44% are protected. 2.11 BDZ's communications are based on small carrier system, operated for about 80% by cable and for the remainder over aerial pole route, with the steel wire needing to be replaced (over 20 years old and with insufficient capacity). There are a total of 112 telephone exchanges serving about 25,000 extensions (1930 German technology needing replacement). A data transmission network between centers Sofia, Plovdiv, Gorna and Vama using x.25 with speed 9.6 k bound, is primarily used for the wagon control. Train radio, covers about 1200 km of trunk lines and some locomotives. Improved communications, replacement of aerial wires, telephone systems and train radio extensions are needed and will be financed by the project. Motive Power and Rolling Stock 2.12 The proportion of traffic hauled by electric traction rose from 76% in 1986 to 85% in 1993. BDZ operates 347 electric and 220 mainline diesel electric locomotives of which about 34% and 37% respectively are over 20 years old. Availability of electric and diesel locomotives in 1993 was about 84% and 78% respectively. It dropped to about 62% in 1994 due to shortages of spare parts (Table 4). The passenger fleet consists of about 2,000 units with a capacity of about 126,000 seats. Almost 50% is over 20 years old. There are over 37,000 freight wagons with a total capacity of 1.9 million tons and an average capacity of about 51 tons, some 20% are over 20 years old. Availability for both coaches and wagons is sufficient, largely because of the excess supply resulting from the decreased traffic.
 2.13 The technical parameters of the traction fleet remain behind in terms of speed and other performance criteria compared to Western European Railways. In aggregate terms, fleet capacity for traction and rolling stock exceeds actual and expected traffic demand, but the fleet does not meet qualitative and structural requirements and should be progressively modernized, at a pace consistent with financial constraints. Reduction of the fleet is part of the Restructuring Action Plan (RAP) (para. 2.40). Workshops and Depots 2.14 There are 15 workshops, all in generally bad conditions (2 for infrastructure, 2 for locomotives, 5 for wagons, 3 for coaches, and 3 for containers) and 32 locomotive depots. The rationalization of fleet types and spare parts inventory, along with fewer re- equipped maintenance depots will bring great economy and improved efficiency once the backlog of maintenance, rehabilitation and modifications has been completed. The heavy repair workshops are outdated and in need of rationalization, re-design and re-equipment. Their workload will decline as fleet sizes reduce and as BDZ introduces maintenance practices based on component exchange rather than heavy overhauls in main works. Workshops that have markets outside the railways such as container manufacturing and the foundry can be separated immediately, with the objective of privatization. Workshops necessary for the maintenance and operation of traction and rolling stock would remain with BDZ, but would be reduced in number and the remaining ones modernized to increase efficiency. Joint venture companies with BDZ's participation are also an option. Surplus workshops would be separated from BDZ for sale or closing down. The timetable for this program is in the RAP (para 2.40). Marshalling Yards 2.15 BDZ operated with 14 marshalling yards until the introduction of a new timetable in January 1994 when eight yards were closed and marshalling operation are now regrouped in six major mechanized yards in Sofia, Plovdiv, Varna, Gorna, Ruse and Burgas (see Map). C. Traffic 2.16 The major political changes in CEE countries have been accompanied by massive economic and industrial upheaval which have profoundly affected railway traffic. With the collapse of the Council of Mutual Assistance (CMEA or COMECON), trading relationships and traffic movements between and within member countries have been undergoing vast changes in volume and patterns. Economic and industrial structures are changing; markets are altering or disappearing; old products and demand patterns for raw materials are declining; the dominance of railways, created by centrally planned command economies, is declining and demand for railway services is being eroded by emerging competition from road transport. The quality and level of railway services have deteriorated due to continued reliance on traditional operating methods, low productivity, increasing costs and inability to invest in modern working system, technology and management techniques. The requirements of the customer have not been met because the railways lack a commercial orientation and the concept of marketing is barely recognized.
 -8- Freight Traffic 2.17 From its peak in 1986, freight traffic fell 57% in terms of tkm (from 18.3 billion to 7.8 billion in 1994) and 65% in terms of tonnage (from 85 million tons to 30 million in 1994). The average length of haul increased from 215 km to 260 km. In 1993 and 1994, traffic stabilized and remained close to the level reached in 1992. Most BDZ freight traffic is domestic and has been affected by the level and structure of domestic economic activity and to a lesser extent by road competition. International trade plays a relatively small part in BDZ's operations with exports, imports and transit accounting for less than 10% of the freight traffic (Table 5). It has been affected lately by the situation in former Yugoslavia. Passenger Traffic 2.18 Passenger traffic did not decrease as much as freight, going down only 36%, from 8.0 billion passenger-km in 1986 to 5. 1 billion in 1994. International passenger traffic is of minor importance and is less than 3% of the total (Table 6). Future Traffic 2.19 In the present economic and political circumstances, both domestic and external, the uncertainties surrounding forecasts must be emphasized. Railway freight traffic may continue to hold up its new present level, provided BDZ adopts an active market-based approach catering to identified customer needs. The restructuring process may well hold the key to success or failure here. Certain specialized international operations such as transshipment through Varna to Black Sea destinations, inter-modal operations with Rhein- Main-Danube shipping and connections to Thessaloniki could, and probably will, assume importance in the future. 2.20 Passenger traffic is particularly difficult to forecast at this time, but can be expected to decline in the medium to longer term given the negative population growth, the growing car ownership and particularly the nascent competition of buses offering competitive services. The rate of decrease will depend on general economic conditions (affecting consumer expenditure and car ownership), the outcome of the BDZ restructuring process, fares policy and the approach adopted to public service contracts. 2.21 Taking into account recent trends in rail traffic volumes and the above mentioned factors, it appears realistic to base the project on figures which do not assume any traffic growth from the 1994 base. Operations 2.22 In 1993, BDZ's operational performance showed either stagnation or decrease compared to 1986 due to continued sharp decrease in traffic, notably in the utilization of rolling stock (passenger and freight services) and in the availability of electric and diesel locomotives (Table 4). BDZ needs to avoid unnecessary maintenance of surplus traction and rolling stock. The availability rate should be lifted by first scrapping surplus wagons, and then assessing whether maintenance efforts need to be intensified. Targets for utilization and availability have been agreed as part of the RAP (Annex 1). 2.23 Freight train operations have been traditional with "wagon load" working between a large number of terminals (about 400), with about 120 trains per day and average train load of 1,170 t/train. About 40% of tonnage loaded is in block-trains. About 75% of traffic passes through private industrial sidings. The new operating system introduced in January 1994, established a timetable for delivery within three time zones of 24, 36 and 48 hours and reduced marshalling. To further reduce costs, future BDZ freight services should be based on the following principles: (i) customer-designed transport of bulk freight to and from main production sites, and to a small number of key distribution centers; (ii) trainload operations of containers between ports and between key inland handling depots; and (iii) international freight operations for container and bulk material movement. 2.24 Passenger traffic is more widely spread than freight but there is a large number of stations with low volumes. Many have been already closed or reduced to unmanned halts and this program will continue. The quality of passenger environment on and off trains is poor. Average train loads are high but, in some cases, excessive provision of accommodation is apparent. The domestic passenger train services were restructured in January 1994 into intercity and regional trains. Poorly occupied and costly long distance regular trains were cancelled. The new timetable, adjusted further in May 1994, includes: (i) 'express' trains between major cities with frequency of two hours or four hours; (ii) international passenger services where these are commercially feasible; (iii) complementary 'stopping' mainline train service for intermediate stations/halts where passenger traffic justifies; (iv) branch line passenger service at minimum cost; and (v) commuter services operated as part of integrated urban transport networks (service retention only in cases where a socio-economic return is demonstrated).
 - 10 - E. Tariffs and Costs 2.25 Legally, BDZ is free to set its tariffs for both freight and passengers. In reality, BDZ's proposals have to be agreed with the Government, including, in the case of passenger tariffs, representatives of the trade unions and political parties. Both freight and passenger tariffs have lagged behind inflation since 1990 (by December 1993, freight tariffs had increased 15 fold and passenger tariffs 10 fold, while general price indices had increased about 18 fold). Freight tariffs were raised fairly regularly. For passengers, however, a six- fold increase in early 1991 was rolled back within 15 days to a four-fold increase and tariffs were not raised again until June 1993. Passenger tariffs were increased further by 65% on June 1, 1994 and again by 39% on January 1, 1995. With this increase, passenger tariffs are now 313% above their May 31, 1993 level, i.e. a 45% increase in real terms. In 1994, average revenues were Leva 0.83/tkm for freight and 0.27/pkm for passenger. Typically in Western Europe, Japan and North America, unit passenger revenues are substantially higher than unit freight revenues. This is another illustration of the lag affecting passenger tariffs. It also reflects the fact that about half the passengers travel with a discount mandated by the Government. The RAP provides for further passenger tariffs increases of 20% per year in real terms until they almost double by 2000 (para. 2.40). 2.26 Costs of fuel and materials have doubled between 1991 and 1993, and staff costs including social insurance have almost quadrupled (360%). Although detailed costing by activity is not available, estimates indicate that freight traffic covers its costs, including its share of the joint costs, while passenger traffic cover only about one-third of its costs. However, elimination of passenger service is not always possible because alternative means of transport have not been developed yet; in such cases the government should compensate BDZ for the services provided; this will be reflected in the contract plan. F. Budget. Accounting and Audit Planning and Budgeting 2.27 BDZ's present planning and budgeting principles and procedures do not meet the needs of a commercially oriented railway for the following reasons: (a) the planning cycle covers one year only while the nature of the railway transport business requires longer perspectives; (b) the focus of past budgets has concentrated on expenditures with little consideration to the revenues potential; (c) revenue budgets are not established by specialists in the marketing and commercial functions; and (d) there is limited involvement in the planning process at lower levels of the organization, leading to little sense of accountability for achieving budgeted performances.
 - 11 - 2.28 To make up for the above deficiencies, BDZ should institutionalize the annual preparation of a five-year revolving financial plan, the first year of which would provide the basis for annual detailed budgets. This revision in BDZ's Planning and Budgeting functions is included in the reorganization of the railway's Finance and Accounting Department described below. Accounting Existing Situation 2.29 BDZ's accounting policies used are generally in accordance with internationally accepted accounting principles. The accounting system may be summarized as being: - standardized throughout the organization; - principally manual based; - geared towards meeting statutory external reporting requirements and; - inadequate to provide management accounting and traffic costing information needed for monitoring BDZ's operating efficiency and financial viability. 2.30 BDZ's present financial management, accounting and financial reporting is based on 141 operating units (called cost or profit centers) spread over the four Railway Regions and Headquarters. No unit conforms strictly to the modern definition of a cost or profit center. Each operating unit has an economics and planning section and a separate accounting section. The economics and planning unit is essentially a management accounting function, while the accounting function covers financial accounting matters. 2.31 With effect from April 1991, BDZ has complied with the requirements of the new Bulgarian Accounting Law. One adverse effect of this compliance has been the loss of detailed production of data for railway operations, further limiting BDZ's ability to cost rail operations so as to establish cost-based tariffs, which is essential for operating a commercially oriented Railway. Reorganization of BDZ's Financial Management and Accounting Function 2.32 There is a critical need to streamline and modernize BDZ's financial and accounting organization and procedures in order to adapt them to the needs of a commercially oriented and financially viable entity. There are no capacity increasing investments. Benefits of the project will be in terms of cost savings and improved safety and quality of service. Track Renewal and Maintenance on Priority Lines 5.2 This is the largest component, accounting for about two-thirds of total project cost. It includes track renewal on major routes as well as plant and equipment for track maintenance. The proposed project focuses on selected track renewal on Lines 1, 2, 3, 5 and 8 which are the main priority rail routes in Bulgaria and have a total length of 1,880 km. Track renewal and medium range maintenance are already overdue on 25% (526 km) of this network, considering the two standard criteria of accumulated gross ton-kilometers and the number of years since the last major maintenance investment. However, because regular maintenance has also been curtailed, and poor quality materials were used in previous rehabilitation work, in practice nearly half (930 km) the total length of these five priority lines are currently subject to speed restrictions due to track condition. Priority sections for renewal (about 400 km) have been identified on the basis of a thorough analysis of track conditions and importance of the traffic. 5.3 Poor track condition causes BDZ serious problems: a) speed restrictions must be imposed and these mean that a larger fleet of locomotives and other rolling stock is required to carry a given volume of traffic; b) in some cases additional restrictions on permissible axles loadings are necessary; c) sub-standard track condition increases the cost of maintaining locomotives and rolling stock; d) many passenger services now take longer than the bus journey on the same route and this, together with passenger discomfort, reduces the attractiveness of the railway and exacerbates the loss of traffic to road; e) inadequate track maintenance increases the risk of derailments which carry a heavy penalty in terms of operation disruption, and can result in damage to the environment or, in a worst case, death and injury; and f) when timely track maintenance is not undertaken, the subsequent cost of bringing the track back to its normal operating condition increases substantially. Furthermore, the accumulated backlog of track maintenance becomes an increasingly significant burden - both financial and operational - on BDZ. 5.4 Benefits. Restoring the track to its normal operating condition would give rise to benefits which would result from: - removal of speed restrictions; - reduced future maintenance costs; - reduced incidence of derailments. The evaluation period is taken as thirteen years (i.e., three years for project implementation plus ten years of operation). Traffic on the five lines to be improved under the project is estimated to comprise 60% of total traffic. The "without-project" alternative is not a "do-nothing" alternative because the present poor condition of the track requires significant maintenance effort in order to provide the minimum conditions necessary for safe train operations. It is therefore assumed that the alternative to carrying out the investments
 - 27 - proposed under the project would be a more gradual implementation of the required major periodic maintenance. It is assumed that it would take about ten years to achieve approximately the same level of track rehabilitation which would be obtained in three years with the project. 5.5 Based on the above, the internal rate of return (IRR) of the investment in track renewal and track maintenance equipment is 34%. Including passenger time savings, this increases to 40%. Detailed analysis of the benefits and calculations are in the Project File. Management Information System 5.6 The introduction of improved management information system would bring the following benefits: reduce expenditures on foreign wagons used in Bulgaria and better control of domestic freight cars, better control of sales of passenger tickets which combined with improved financial management, particularly the cash flow will result in reduced interest costs. The IRR for this equipment is estimated at 22%. Risks 5.7 Given the political uncertainties in Bulgaria, there is a risk that some of the more difficult decisions embodied in the RAP regarding staff reductions, tariff increases, etc. will be delayed. There is also a risk for some shift of traffic away from rail if the railways do not clearly assess the needs of the markets in this period of transition in the economy. The measures taken up-front (para. 2.38) indicate that the railways and Government are committed to restructuring. The proposed mid-term review (para. 3.16) would provide an opportunity to assess the situation and recommend any changes in the project that may be required. The physical components do not pose significant risks, since all investments are for rehabilitation of the core components of the system which would have high priority under any restructuring scenario.  -53- ANNEX 3 Page 1 of 5 BULGARIA RAILWAY REHABILITATION PROJECT Environmental Review Environmental management in the Bulgarian State Railways (BDZ). 1. The railways provide a way of transportation which is safer for the environment compared to their main competitor, the automobile transport. The impact of rail operations on air pollution is minimal and there are no severe problems associated with traffic noise, water pollution, soil contamination in loading and unloading areas, spills of hazardous cargo and waste disposal. In compliance with the Bulgarian Environmental Impact Assessment Regulation, for all investment projects in the railways (including reconstruction and rehabilitation projects) assessments of the potential negative environmental impacts and mitigation plans are required. In order to address the environmental problems occurring in operations, cars and locomotives manufacturing and maintenance, and car hygiene provision, and to comply with the environmental laws and regulations, environmental management functions are allocated in three different departments of BDZ. The technical specialists in these departments are highly qualified and competent in their field, although unexperienced in operating in a market oriented environment. 2. Compliance with environmental laws and regulations and provision of overall environmental expertise. These functions are delegated to the Department for Strategic Development, which is in charge of restructuring planning and BDZ's adjustment to the new market conditions. The department employs one full time environmental economist in the central administration, who coordinates all so called "designated environmental experts" in the BDZ's branches (usually those are the labor safety experts whose position descriptions include environmental protection). It appears that the delegation of responsibilities to "designated experts" is rather formal (during mission visits to depot and workshops where non-compliance with environmental standards occur no such experts were present). In addition, the Department for Strategic Development has a core group of experts currently working on incorporating environmental considerations in the strategy for railway development. In particular, they are assisting the BDZ's management in assessing the full social costs for different types of transportation, comparing accident rates and environmental externalities between the road and rail transport. 3. Veterinarian and disinfection control in railways operation. A Sanitary Department (7 experts, directly reporting to the Director General of the BDZ) manages veterinarian and disinfection control, practiced by 13 regional specialized stations (with staff of 248). The railway sanitary service was created in 1934, using German and Austro-Hungarian models. Until 1976 the department and the specialized sanitary stations provided services exclusively to the BDZ. In 1976 the Department was reorganized into a Transport System Sanitation Service,
 -54- ANNEX 3 Page 2 of 5 and all means of transport (rail, water, air and auto-transport) have been given access to the existing facilities. Nonetheless, it continues to be under the direct supervision of BDZ's Director General in order to ensure the maintenance of the above services during the economic transition. 4. Management of landscape and track maintenance. Landscape rehabilitation, afforestation and track maintenance are carried out by a separate Department under the Director General, with a total staff of 224. While the Department is mostly concerned with track safety, it is also responsible for environmental protection of the track areas. Aside of issues related to use of chemicals in vegetation control, the staff of this Department is experiencing problems with their landscape rehabilitation activities, mostly resulting from inefficient coordination with the environmental authorities on nature conservation (permission from the Ministry of Environment or the Regional Environmental Inspectorates is required for deforestation, afforestation, and terrain maintenance). 5. In addition to the above functions, regulations and control of hazardous materials transportation are provided by a Department for Hazardous Cargo (a military unit in the central BDZ administration). 6. Issues and recommendations. Currently there is little coordination among the Departments addressing the above environmental issues. It appears that no company-wide environmental assessment and planning has been carried out. At negotiations, it should be agreed that the Department for Strategic Development should incorporate in the job description of the environmental specialist: (i) environmental performance assessment of BDZ's branches; (ii) setting priorities for BDZ's environmental expenditures; (iii) internal coordination on the environmental activities; and (iv) development and implementation of standard reporting procedures. Training should be provided on environmental impact assessment and auditing regulations, on low cost sanitation and on market-based incentives for environmental protection. Key Environmental Problems in Railway Operation and Maintenance. 7. Normal concerns for railways such as disposal of waste (including oil), cleaning of tank settlements, water treatment, use of chemicals for track maintenance, and transport of hazardous materials are covered by the national environmental legislation and regulations, and mitigation measures are in place in BDZ practice. Still problems exist, resulting both from shortcomings of the regulatory framework and to weak enforcement. Among those are: (i) waste water discharge and treatment in some depots and maintenance stations (especially the outdated ones); (ii) solid waste disposal; (iii) use of chemicals for track maintenance; (iv) development and enforcement of safety and hygiene instructions and procedures; and (v) staff performance quality. 8. Waste Water Discharge and Treatment. Waste water discharge appears to be the most significant case of systematic violation of Bulgaria's environmental standards by the railways. Nine of BDZ's depot, workstations and plants have been paying non-compliance sanctions to the environmental authorities on a regular basis. In 1993 the railways paid a total of 1,238,485
 -55- ANNEX 3 Page 3 of 5 Leva. The sanctions were spread unevenly among the separate polluters. According to the data for the level of these sanctions for each of the nine violators, two of the depots were charged with 93 percent of the total amount (Sofia Depot paid 77 percent of the 1993 sanctions, and Drujba Depot paid another 15 percent). Four factors seem to constrain efficient response to waste water discharge problems: (i) lack of funding; (ii) obsolete facilities and/or lack of appropriate space for construction of waste water treatment plants; (iii) low level of the sanctions (below the costs of abatement) causing disincentive; and (iv) low priority of environmental issues for some branch managers. In depot and workshops where the management is proactive both good housekeeping and low cost solutions are implemented and the pollution problems are significantly reduced. For example, use of sediment depositors and bypasses for waste water discharge in the city collector eliminated the need of local waste water treatment facility in Nadezda Depot in Sofia. 9. Waste disposal. Solid waste is generated both in operations and maintenance. In operations, waste problems (passenger and cargo waste) occur mostly in the depot and maintenance stations. While for passenger waste the key problem is waste disposal, leftovers in cars from freight cargo could also lead to soil and ground water contamination, and create health risks for the maintenance staff. Freight cars are often sent for maintenance with non- identified, possibly hazardous, cargo leftovers. Trash is often spread around stations and along the tracks (caused by improper loading, unloading and handling, passengers neglect and lack of proper sites). Scrap from maintenance, as well as from decommissioning of locomotives and cars, is normally sold for recycling. Inefficiency of the responsible central administration service, low scrap prices and insufficient economic incentives for the local staff restrict scrap sales and recycling. A particular problem is reselling/reuse of steel and nickel car batteries. They are often stored on the ground, creating risk of soil and ground water contamination. 10. Chemical application. All chemicals for track maintenance are tested and approved by the National Center for Hygiene, and by the Ministry of Agriculture. There are procedures for chemicals application, which should minimize health risks for the Departmental staff, employed in track maintenance, and prevent the spread of chemicals over agricultural land. Due to lack of specialized track maintenance cars, and to staff negligence, these procedures are not always followed. 11. Veterinarian control and car hygiene. Currently there are 13 specialized stations. An Ordinance of the Director General specifies where should a railcar be sent for disinfection, depending on the cargo, for which it was last used. The stations have a good record with the environmental authorities (only one fine was reported for improper handling of railcars after the transportation of hazardous cargo). All stations operate according to regulations for hygiene parameters, usage of cleaning chemicals and hygiene control. An Operational Manual for these station is incorporated in the Veterinarian Activities Act. 12. Most of the existing stations need rehabilitation and expansion. In almost all of them the existing waste water treatment facilities are inadequate. Incinerators are available only at airports, and often waste is stored in municipal waste disposal sites without proper handling. Freight cars are repeatedly not directed to the stations by station personnel (either due to
 -56- ANNEX 3 Page 4 of 5 shortage of cars, or because of low qualification of the staff, involved in loading and unloading operations). Since autocars are not exposed to the same hygiene control as rail cars, cargo transfer from auto to rail cars causes hygiene risks to the railway. Although since 1981 the state autotransport companies have been required to control car hygiene, the newly expanding private carriers avoid the control. Strengthening the sanitary control is needed at the borders. A new sanitary station should be constructed at the border with Turkey (near Svilengrad). 13. Currently the managerial and financial organization of the railways does not encourage cost recovery in freight car cleaning. Both revenues from and expenditures for the hygiene services are centralized in BDZ's consolidated budget. The tariffs for these services are not linked to costs (only for oil cars cleaning the tariff is set at a higher level). In addition, the costs for cleaning for some types of cargo are higher than the fine that can be imposed on the user for violating the sanitary regulations. Many users prefer to pay the fines and transfer the responsibility and the costs for car cleaning to the sanitary stations. 14. Hygiene regulations and procedures. Existing regulations specify in details hygiene requirements in railway operations and maintenance. There are, however, two areas where further work would be needed to improve cargo specifications: (i) regulations for proper treatment of freight cars after use); and (ii) instructions for dealing with the consequences of accidents with hazardous cargos. 15. Staff performance. Most of the environmental problems caused by the railways are escalated by bad housekeeping and staff negligence. Services like waste handling and disposal are very unattractive and even the current high unemployment level does not assure reliable staff. Some of the BDZ's branches are contracting hygiene services to private firms, which seems to contribute to quality improvements. There are, however, trade union constraints to broader application of the contracting practice, since it leads to loss of permanent jobs. 16. Conclusions and recommendations. In short and medium term the BDZ' financial situation would allow only limited investments in environmental protection. On the other hand, further tightening of pollution control and increase in the level of pollution sanctions and charges would help to address the most serious environmental problems of the BDZ. The Department for Strategic Development, in collaboration with the environmental authorities, should prepare environmental performance assessment of the railways and set priorities for environmental expenditures within the budget constraint. Rehabilitation of existing facilities (e. g. the waste incinerator in Nadezda Depot, the waste water facility in Sofia Depot etc.) and completion of advanced projects (e. g. train wash station in Plovdiv) should be given priority. Proper pricing of the environmental services (e. g. car hygiene, landscape maintenance, terrain rehabilitation) should be imposed to encourage efficient resource allocation. Some of the above services should be privatized. Environmental Consequences from Railway Rehabilitation and Restructuring. 17. Railway rehabilitation would improve the competitiveness of the railway versus its main competitor, the automobile transport, and would bring overall environmental benefits. There
 -57- ANNEX 3 Page 5 of 5 could be, however, environmental consequences of lines/stations closures that may require mitigation measures (e. g. clean up of polluted loading and unloading areas, as well as of waste disposal sites; liquidation of abandoned underground and above ground storage tanks used for hazardous chemicals; removal of transformers and other facilities). 18. These consequences have not been overseen by the existing regulations. The appraisal team assisted the Ministry of Environment in the drafting of a new Environmental Audits Regulation, which would allow the development of auditing procedures for lines and stations closures. Until this Regulation is approved by the Council of Ministers, all restructuring activities in the railways (both within and outside of the scope of this project) would be reviewed by the Regional Environmental Inspectorates or the Ministry of Environment, depending on the scale and the expected environmental consequences of any particular restructuring operation. 19. The restructuring of BDZ responds to declining railways share of passenger and freight traffic and targets improved performance of the company. There are, however, environmental concerns related to the rapid increase of road transportation. In response to it the Ministry of Environment plans to introduce gasoline charges, linked to the air pollution from motor vehicles, which would internalize some of the externalities from the road transport. Such measure would have comparative advantages for the railways. The Ministry of Environment intends to prepare a study to assess the environmental consequences from different transport strategies, and to design economic instruments for internalizing the environmental externalities from the automobile transport. If this study is undertaken, it would complement current efforts of BDZ staff to assess and compare the full social costs of the rail and the road transport. Operational implications 20. doc.abstracts: The Railway Rehabilitation Project will support and deepen the restructuring process which the Railways and Government have initiated. The project supports a set of policy measures that will be embodied in new railway law, the Restructuring Action Plan and a Contract Plan with the Government. The project will finance necessary investments which will be in line with the restructuring concept and will help the railway through the restructuring process. This includes: (a) track renewal and maintenance on priority routes; (v) management information systems; (c) signalling and telecommunications; (d) traction and rolling stock improvements; (e) rehabilitation of passenger coaches; and (f) training and technical assistance.
